item.title: Blue Volta is dead, long live Blue Volta!
item.dc:creator: Luca
item.description:
We knew that developing a game would not be easy, and that looking for someone to finance a classic point and click graphic adventure in 2017 would have made us sweat a lot. However, something happened that forced us to slow down and re-evaluate the project overall: life. Read more »

The post Blue Volta is dead, long live Blue Volta! appeared first on Ossocubo.
item.content:encoded:
ENGLISH

We knew that developing a game would not be easy, and that looking for someone to finance a classic point and click graphic adventure in 2017 would have made us sweat a lot. However, something happened that forced us to slow down and re-evaluate the project overall: life.

Let me explain: between 2017 and 2018 we contacted various publishers looking for a solid base to be able to develop Blue Volta and survive (aka “eating panini”). Unfortunately, classic adventures scare people away when we talk about money to invest and the situation, considering a project like ours, did not allow us to satisfy our favourite habit, that is, to live.

We therefore interrupted the project to dedicate ourselves to our work, but we never stopped thinking about how to recover Blue Volta and complete its development. I don’t think that graphic adventures are dead, but it wasn’t feasible to develop Blue Volta in that capacity and with its features, so we decided to tell the same story with the same characters, changing the genre.

Blue Volta is no longer a graphic adventure.

Blue Volta is an adventure focused on plot, characters and choices, with pad control and platform exploration phases.

Are you still here? Are you still interested?
Well, we have a newsletter for you (you can sign up here).
Development is going great and we have a lot to tell.

Meanwhile, I leave you with a screenshot.

Luca

ITALIANO

Sapevamo che sviluppare un gioco non sarebbe stato facile e che cercare qualcuno che finanziasse un’avventura grafica punta e clicca classica nel 2017 ci avrebbe fatto sudare parecchio, ma poi è successa una cosa che ci ha costretti a frenare e rivalutare il progetto nel complesso: la vita.

Mi spiego meglio: tra il 2017 e il 2018 abbiamo contattato vari publisher in cerca di una base solida per poter sviluppare Blue Volta e sopravvivere (aka “mangiare i panini”). Purtroppo gli adventure classici spaventano quando si parla di soldi da investire e la situazione, davanti a un progetto come il nostro, non ci permetteva di soddisfare il nostro vizio preferito, ovvero campare.

Abbiamo quindi interrotto il progetto per dedicarci ai nostri lavori, senza mai smettere di pensare a come recuperare Blue Volta e completarne lo sviluppo. Non penso che le avventure grafiche siano morte, ma non era fattibile sviluppare Blue Volta in quella veste e con le sue caratteristiche, così abbiamo deciso di raccontare la medesima storia con gli stessi personaggi, cambiandone il genere.

Blue Volta non è più un’avventura grafica.

Blue Volta è un adventure focalizzato su trama, personaggi e scelte, con controllo via pad e fasi d’esplorazione platform.

Siete ancora qui? Siete ancora interessati?
Beh, abbiamo un newsletter apposta per voi (potete iscrivervi qui) e vi giuriamo che non vi manderemo una notizia ogni tre anni.
Lo sviluppo sta andando alla grande e abbiamo tantissimo da raccontare.
Intanto vi lascio con uno screenshot.

Luca

item.content:encoded:
We have a composer for Blue Volta. After a long search for someone who would share our vision on Blue Volta, we can finally say that we found the right musician for the project.
So we officially welcome aboard Paolo Giacci, talented composer made in Abruzzo.

https://www.paologiacci.com

Paolo is working on the score of Blue Volta since some time now and the result is exactly what we wanted, as he managed to blend his compositions with the atmospheres we are building around Zeno and his story.

I’ll leave you with a little moody taste of the Blue Volta soundtrack.

Luca

item.content:encoded:
Last weekend we were guests of Game Over Milano, an underground Italian Indie Developers festival.
For the occasion we decided to bring a “beefier” version of Blue Volta‘s demo, and it has been warmly welcomed. We received lots of impressions and suggestions, which will help us improve the game as much as possible.

 



We would like to thank the Game Over organisers that also this year allowed us into the event, Flupazzi for creating our marvellous mascot, all of our developer friends (you are so many!) and whoever stopped by to try the game or just to say hello.

Now it’s time to get back to work. Our first objective is near and we have plenty of enthusiasm to ride.

item.title: So… what’s the plan?
item.dc:creator: Luca
item.description:
Until a couple of months ago, the search for a publisher was not a priority for us. At first, Blue Volta was a project to express our strengths and skills, which we worked on in our spare time. As time has passed, Blue Volta has grown in shape and size, to become a focused full-time... Read more »

The post So… what’s the plan? appeared first on Ossocubo.
item.content:encoded:
Until a couple of months ago, the search for a publisher was not a priority for us. At first, Blue Volta was a project to express our strengths and skills, which we worked on in our spare time. As time has passed, Blue Volta has grown in shape and size, to become a focused full-time project.

For this reason, we are currently working to develop a playable version of the first chapter of the game. The aim is to be able to provide a polished and concrete demo version to help us in our search for funds and financing.

 

A typical Ossocubo meeting basically consists of me, Mattia and Francesco shouting orders to Alberto and watching him at work

 

Personally, I’m very happy with how well the demo, a labour of love, is coming along, but is still a work-in-progress. For instance, we have had a lot of interest from many talented composers to cover the audio aspect of the game (e.g. soundtrack and soundeffects). We are still receiving e-mails expressing interest, and we will soon begin to assess and contact the right person or persons for the job.

While the sound is definitely the less developed side of the Blue Volta, there are so other areas that need further refinement, such as animations and interface. Despite all this, the demo is at a well-advanced stage.

During this week, I’ll adjust some dialogues, write some new ones, and finalize a couple of puzzles.

item.content:encoded:
Hi folks and welcome to Ossocubo’s devlog! Yay!

You know, we have been thinking for a while about whether or not to open a devlog.
We were all concerned about the actual amount of interesting things to say or the quality of the material to show, but since the development of Blue Volta has become a real thing in the latest weeks, we decided to act bravely enough to open this promising page.

The plan is basically to publish at least a post a week in which me, or the other Ossocubo’s guys, will talk about news concerning the development of our projects and other activities of the team, all without spoilers.

Obviously we will also talk about other topics, as Blue Volta is only our first project… so who knows what the future holds! But there’s no need to rush, so lets enjoy one moment at a time on a peaceful and constant zen flow.

So, please have a seat and make yourself confortable: we hope you’ll enjoy the ride!

Luca
